elements.title: σ-Bond insertion reactions of two strained diradicaloids (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
σ-Bond insertion reactions of two strained diradicaloids

  • Arismel Tena Meza
  • Christina A. Rivera
  • Neil K. Garg
Article12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Observation of Plastic Ice VII by Quasi-Elastic Neutron Scattering (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Observation of Plastic Ice VII by Quasi-Elastic Neutron Scattering

  • Maria Rescigno
  • Alberto Toffano
  • Livia Eleonora Bove
Article12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Observation of an ultra-high-energy cosmic neutrino with KM3NeT (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Observation of an ultra-high-energy cosmic neutrino with KM3NeT

A very high-energy muon observed by the KM3NeT experiment in the Mediterranean Sea is evidence for the interaction of an exceptionally high-energy neutrino of cosmic origin.  

  • S. Aiello
  • A. Albert
  • N. Zywucka
ArticleOpen Access12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Learning produces an orthogonalized state machine in the hippocampus (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Learning produces an orthogonalized state machine in the hippocampus

Insight into the algorithmic form and learning principles underlying cognitive maps in the hippocampus is provided.

  • Weinan Sun
  • Johan Winnubst
  • Nelson Spruston
ArticleOpen Access12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Transcriptional adaptation upregulates utrophin in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Transcriptional adaptation upregulates utrophin in Duchenne muscular dystrophy

Transcriptional adaptation upregulates UTRN in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) patients, as supported by several lines of evidence, including the use of splice-switching antisense oligonucleotides to induce the skipping of out-of-frame exons of the DMD gene.

  • Lara Falcucci
  • Christopher M. Dooley
  • Didier Y. R. Stainier
ArticleOpen Access12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Transcriptomic neuron types vary topographically in function and morphology (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Transcriptomic neuron types vary topographically in function and morphology

Transcriptomic profiling of neurons from the zebrafish optic tectum identified more than 60 cell types; functional imaging revealed that response tuning, morphology and connectivity of specific cell types vary systematically with the neurons’ positions in the tissue.

  • Inbal Shainer
  • Johannes M. Kappel
  • Herwig Baier
ArticleOpen Access12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Topological segregation of stress sensors along the gut crypt–villus axis (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Topological segregation of stress sensors along the gut crypt–villus axis

Serotonergic enterochromaffin cells of the intestine exhibit distinct sensory, secretory and physiological properties depending on their location within the complex crypt–villus architecture of the gut.

  • Kouki K. Touhara
  • Nathan D. Rossen
  • David Julius
Article12 Feb 2025

elements.title: A metagenomic ‘dark matter’ enzyme catalyses oxidative cellulose conversion (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
A metagenomic ‘dark matter’ enzyme catalyses oxidative cellulose conversion

A metalloenzyme capable of oxidatively cleaving cellulose, found in a microbial community specialized in lignocellulose degradation, could enable sustainable biofuel production.

  • Clelton A. Santos
  • Mariana A. B. Morais
  • Mario T. Murakami
ArticleOpen Access12 Feb 2025

elements.title: UM171 glues asymmetric CRL3–HDAC1/2 assembly to degrade CoREST corepressors (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
UM171 glues asymmetric CRL3–HDAC1/2 assembly to degrade CoREST corepressors

UM171 promotes corepressor degradation by acting as a molecular glue to induce KBTBD4–HDAC1/2 interactions with the help of inositol hexakisphosphate.

  • Megan J. R. Yeo
  • Olivia Zhang
  • Ning Zheng
ArticleOpen Access12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Global engineering effects of soil invertebrates on ecosystem functions (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Global engineering effects of soil invertebrates on ecosystem functions

A meta-analysis of more than 1,000 studies reveals the global ecosystem functions provided by termites, ants and earthworms as they improve soil quality by making biogenic structures such as termite mounds, ant hills and earthworm casts.

  • Donghao Wu
  • Enzai Du
  • Chengjin Chu
Article12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Genetic architecture in Greenland is shaped by demography, structure and selection (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Genetic architecture in Greenland is shaped by demography, structure and selection

We illustrate that including data from Greenlandic Inuit can greatly reduce inequity in genomic-based healthcare in Greenland and other indigenous Arctic populations.

  • Frederik Filip Stæger
  • Mette K. Andersen
  • Anders Albrechtsen
ArticleOpen Access12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Macrophages protect against sensory axon loss in peripheral neuropathy (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Macrophages protect against sensory axon loss in peripheral neuropathy

A study in a mouse model of obesity and prediabetes demonstrates that recruitment of macrophages to nerves has a protective role in diet-induced peripheral neuropathy.

  • Sara Hakim
  • Aakanksha Jain
  • Clifford J. Woolf
ArticleOpen Access12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Manipulation of the altermagnetic order in CrSb via crystal symmetry (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Manipulation of the altermagnetic order in CrSb via crystal symmetry

The altermagnetic order in CrSb films can be manipulated via crystal symmetry; the reconstructed altermagnetic order generates a room-temperature spontaneous anomalous Hall effect and designable switching modes as field-assisted and field-free modes.

  • Zhiyuan Zhou
  • Xingkai Cheng
  • Cheng Song
Article12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Shielding Pt/γ-Mo2N by inert nano-overlays enables stable H2 production (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Shielding Pt/γ-Mo2N by inert nano-overlays enables stable H2 production

Atomically dispersed inert oxide nano-overlays on a highly active Pt/γ-Mo2N catalyst can block the redundant surface sites of γ-Mo2N responsible for surface oxidation of this reactive support and the resulting deactivation, without compromising the intrinsic activity of active Pt@Mo2N interface.

  • Zirui Gao
  • Aowen Li
  • Ding Ma
Article12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Intrinsic electrical activity drives small-cell lung cancer progression (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Intrinsic electrical activity drives small-cell lung cancer progression

Electrical excitability in neuroendocrine SCLC cells promotes tumour progression through action potential firing, increasing ATP demand and oxidative phosphorylation dependency, whereas non-neuroendocrine cells provide metabolic support, driving a tumour-autonomous cycle that enhances tumorigenesis and metastasis.

  • Paola Peinado
  • Marco Stazi
  • Leanne Li
ArticleOpen Access12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Hydrogen escaping from a pair of exoplanets smaller than Neptune (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Hydrogen escaping from a pair of exoplanets smaller than Neptune

Ongoing hydrogen loss from two sibling exoplanets provides support for the role of such hydrogen loss in the evolution of close-orbiting sub-Neptunes.

  • R. O. Parke Loyd
  • Ethan Schreyer
  • David R. Ardila
Article12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Aqueous-based recycling of perovskite photovoltaics (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Aqueous-based recycling of perovskite photovoltaics

A recycling strategy based predominantly on the use of water to restore and reuse valuable components from perovskite photovoltaic waste is described, with recycled devices showing similar efficiency and stability compared with fresh devices.

  • Xun Xiao
  • Niansheng Xu
  • Feng Gao
ArticleOpen Access12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Learned magnetic map cues and two mechanisms of magnetoreception in turtles (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Learned magnetic map cues and two mechanisms of magnetoreception in turtles

Loggerhead sea turtles, which undergo long-distance migrations, can learn magnetic signatures associated with different geographic areas and have two different magnetic senses, each based on a different underlying mechanism.

  • Kayla M. Goforth
  • Catherine M. F. Lohmann
  • Kenneth J. Lohmann
Article12 Feb 2025

elements.title: Direct experimental constraints on the spatial extent of a neutrino wavepacket (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Direct experimental constraints on the spatial extent of a neutrino wavepacket

An innovative method using superconducting sensors precisely measures the recoil energy of lithium-7 nuclei, setting a lower limit on the spatial extent of neutrino wavepackets, advancing understanding of neutrino properties and weak nuclear decays.

  • Joseph Smolsky
  • Kyle G. Leach

elements.title: Earliest short-tailed bird from the Late Jurassic of China (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Earliest short-tailed bird from the Late Jurassic of China

Two recently discovered bird fossils from the Late Jurassic Zhenghe Fauna demonstrate that highly derived bird-like features and the origin of birds appeared much earlier in the Jurassic period than previously estimated.

  • Runsheng Chen
  • Min Wang
  • Zhonghe Zhou
Article12 Feb 2025
